Name: Dredd
Description:
“Based on the comic series Judge Dredd. Players share 3 common decks: Judge Deck, Criminal Deck, Event Deck. Each deck has its own discard. A player will keep cards from all 3 decks in his hand. Victory: Be the first player to accumulate 100 Prestige Points. Prestige Points are gained by apprehending Criminals.”

“Teams: Each player controls a team of up to 4 Characters. Most characters will be Judges. Stats: Each Character will have 2 Stats: Fight & Investigate. A Stat will usually have a value between 0 and 4. Characters will also have one or more Traits such as: Judge, Psychic, Alien, etc.”

Name: Drop Troops
Description:
“Futuristic Tactical Miniatures Ruleset. Each player controls a squad of heavily armed Drop Troopers (Space Marines.) For use with typical Space Marine pewter and plastic figs.”

The equipment provided for in the rules includes light and heavy weapons systems, grenades, pistols, hand to hand weapons, power suit systems, and armor. The rules also cover Detection, Ammo depletion, Medical Care, Repairs, Morale, Psionic Abilities, and Neohuman Races.

Name: Duel of Iron
Description: "Civil War era tactical combat simulation. Players each control one or more Ironclads. The rules are for the basic scenario, in which one player controls the Confederate Merrimac, and one player controls the Union Monitor. Use a hex map. Indicate which spaces are land and which are water. Indicate whether water spaces are shallow or deep. Six, eight, and ten sided dice are needed. Use cardboard counters (chits) to represent the ships."

Name: Dungeon Keeper
Description:
“Based on the Computer Game of the same name. Each player controls their own Dungeon, which they try to build up, in spite of a continuing onslaught of Heroes.”

Using a Room Deck and Spell Deck, amass a collection of Rooms, Creatures, Gold, Mana, and dead Heroes – but don’t allow your Dungeon Keeper to be killed or your Heart Room to be captured, as these lead to instant defeat.

Name: Jacked Card Racing
Description:
JACKED is a deck-based trading card racing game, with decks available for different types of tracks, vehicles and modifiers that you can collect and trade with your friends.

With all kinds of JACKED TRACKS and JACKED VEHICLES to choose from, and lots of ways to modify and play them.

Name: Dungeon Master
Description:
“Dungeon Crawl Card game. One Player is the Dungeon Master. The other player is the Party Player. Each player has his own unique deck. The Party Player must create an adventuring party. A party starts with 6 members (Heroes). Pick 10 cards from the Character Deck. Discard 4 and keep 6.”

The Dungeon Master wins the game if all of the Heroes are killed. The Party Player wins the game if the party gains Treasures worth 50 points or more.

Name: Durable Goods
Description: “Economics Game. Players buy raw materials, manufacture products, and then sell them. Each player starts with $50 and no raw materials or products. Raw Materials Deck: The decks consist of 80 cards or chits. The deck contains 20 each of the following raw materials: Wood, Plastic, Metal, Fabric. Manufactured Goods Deck: Also called Durable Goods. Use chits or cards to represent the following manufactured goods: Houses, Furniture, Cars, Appliances, Clothing. Objective: Be the first player to accumulate $500.”

Name: Earth Defense Force
Description:
“Takes place in the Star Blazers Universe. Pick your Fleet: Earth Defense Force, Gamillon Empire, White Comet Empire. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each fleet has five types of ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw their hands from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: East Front West Front
Description: “Card game for 2 players simulating the conflict in Europe in the Second World War. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Each player has his own unique deck. Fronts: There are three fronts: The East Front, the West Front, the Mediterranean Front. Each front is represented by 4 Tokens. (There are 4 East, 4 West, & 4 Med. Tokens) Victory: If the Allied player controls all 4 tokens in any one front he wins. To win, the German player must control all 4 tokens in both the East and West Fronts. If the Germans do not win by the end of 1945, they automatically lose.”

Name: Egypt
Description:
“Card game simulating 3000 years of rule by the Pharaohs of ancient Egypt.” There are seven kinds of cards in the deck. Each turn the players attempt to play the highest scoring meld to establish control of Egypt. A meld is two or more cards of the same type. The player who controls Egypt may then play additional melds from his hand to gain tribute points.

“The game ends after 10 turns. Each turn represents 300 years. If the deck runs out before the 10th turn, shuffle the cards and keep playing. Victory: The player with the most accumulated tribute points at the end of the game is the winner.”

Name: Empires
Description:
“Short rules for a quick play civilization like boardgame.”

Two or more players begin the game with one city and ten counters representing the population and military force. A standard deck of cards is used. A certain type of card, or combination of cards, must be played to perform certain actions in the game. The descriptions of the combinations include: Migration, Merchant, Combat, Apostle, Abundance, Exploration, War, Exodus, Colonization, Crusade, and Foundation.

The object of the game is to control more than half of the provinces on the map. A player who is eliminated may return as a foreign invader, starting with one city and six counters on the outer ring of provinces.

Name: Evolved
Description:
“It took 3.5 billion years to make this game. Winning: The player with the most species at the end of the game wins.”

A game of evolution. Each player starts with a single species. The game is played on a 6x6 grid composed of three kinds of spaces: Land, Open Water, and Islands. The board is also divided into three types of zones: Arctic, Tropical, and Temperate. The game lasts for sixteen turns, with each turn representing a different Geologic Era, Period, or Epoch, from the Archean to the Quaternary.

Name: Exorcist
Description: “Card Game for 2 players. One player is the Exorcist. The other player is the Demon. The Demon has taken possession of a young Innocent. The Exorcist is trying to purge the Demon. Each player has a unique deck. Each player gets 50 Soul Tokens. Victory: The first player to win all the Soul Tokens is the winner.”

Name: Fabulous Thunderbirds
Description:
A game based on the Thunderbirds television show.

The players travel from their Secret Bases to respond to various emergencies determined by card draw. Each emergency requires a certain assortment of vehicles to resolve. All players have an identical assortment of vehicles to work with: "Thunderbird 1" through "Thunderbird 5", and "FAB 1."

The object of the game is to make more rescues that your opponents.

Name: Fairy Circle Ring
Description:
“It is Spring Equinox in the Sylvan woods. The little people, also referred to as Fairies, or Fey have gathered to celebrate. After feasting, storytelling, gossiping, and singing they gather around the Fairy circle ring to play a game they call the Dance of Eights. The fairies dance in groups until they finally form a perfect circle of eight dancers. The winners get laurel leaves and an extra helping of Pixie dust on their elderberries.”

The winner is the first player to build a “ring”, or hand of eight cards, composed of a specified mix of dancers according to their gender, size, alignment, and Earth element.

Name: Fall of France
Description:
“Solo Card Game. 10 May 1940. The player takes the role of the Germans invading the Western Democracies. There are two decks: The Allied Deck and the German Deck.”

To advance your campaign, you must play melds with a higher Force total than the Allied Cards on the table.

“Objective: You win if you run the Allied deck out of cards. The Allied forces collapse and you conquer France in 6 weeks. If you ever accumulate 7 delay tokens, the Allies have stopped you and you must fight a long war against France.”

Name: Fall of the Aztecs
Description:
“Two player set piece strategic game. One player controls the Aztecs. The other player controls the Spaniards and their allies: The Totonac, Tlascalans, Texcocoans, and Cholula. Victory Conditions: The Spaniards must capture the Aztec leader Cuahtemoc. The Aztecs must capture the Spanish leader Cortez.”

The battle is fought on a hex map depicting the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan. Each Aztec unit represents 10,000 Indians. Each Spanish unit represents 100 Spaniards.

Name: Fallujah
Description:
“You control a US Marine Company on Patrol in Fallujah.”

The game uses a custom deck of sixty cards. There are ten different kinds of cards in the deck: Insurgent Tactics, Insurgents, Positions, Explosives, American Tactics, Infantry, Armor, Support , Recon, and Disarm.

The player’s score is based on how many casualties are suffered by the player's Company versus the number inflicted on the enemy.

Name: Fantasy Fight Club
Description:
“Combat between 2 opposing fantasy warbands. Game progresses in 2 stages: Recruit Stage. Battle Stage.”

In the Recruit Stage, the players create their warbands by receiving a random selection of ten warriors to which they must assign their random assortments of weapons and armor cards.

The game is played with five decks of cards -- the Warrior, Weapon, Armor, Spell and Fight Decks.

Name: Fantasy Fighters
Description:
“Card game of Fantasy combat.”

The game is played with a custom deck of fifty cards. Combat consists of playing card combinations which represent specific attacks the fighters can carry out. The fighters also have combinations which can be played in defense. The game comes with statistics for three sample fighters.

Name: Fantasy Heroes
Description:
The game is played with two decks – the Territory Deck and the Battle Deck.

The Territory Deck has fifteen cards, three each of five types: Castles, Mountains, Towers, Forests, and Swamps. The Battle Deck has sixty cards, which come in four different types: Heroes, Minions, Artifacts, and Spells. The Heroes and Minions are each associated with a specific type of Territory.

The object of the game is to control all of the Territory Cards.

Name: Fantasy Skirmish
Description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Fantasy Armies. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single hero, monster, or unit. Victory: You win if you kill all opposing units with Leadership Skill.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player purchases sixteen units using an equal amount of points. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from this shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Name: Farmers
Description:
A card game of competitive farming.

Resource Cards represent crops and animals on the farm. Points are scored by having Resource Cards in play when a matching Market Card is played by any player. In addition, there are Setback Cards which cause all players with certain Resource Cards in play to lose points. The game ends when one or more players reach twenty or more points.

Name: Farmers of Ur
Description: “Players each control a settlement in ancient Mesopotamia. Players are trying to be the first to develop their village into a full-fledged city. This Honor belongs to the first player to build a Ziggurat. Tokens represent the manpower and materials needed to build the Ziggurats. Victory: The first player to accumulate 60 Tokens is the winner. If two players both go over 60 in the same turn, the player with the highest total number of Tokens wins.”

Name: Fiefs
Description:
“Medieval Dukes contest for gold and lands. Object: The player with the most gold at the end of the game wins. Board: The board is a 3x3 grid. The Central square is the Palace. The 8 Surrounding squares are the lesser Fiefs. Deck: Players use a common deck. The deck contains 78 cards.”

Each player starts with one corner Fief, six Gold, three Bishops, four Nobles, five Knights, and a hand of seven cards from a custom card deck. The players obtain gold by controlling squares on the board – one gold for each Fief and two gold for the Palace.

Name: Kagemucca
Description:
The funniest cow war in the world... the Mucca Games party game!

Each player receives a set of cows (Elite, Rookie, Cow Waste "Vaccacca") and place the cards face up. Each player studies the placement of the other players' cards, then the cards are covered.
The current player attacks another players' card with one of his cards: if they are of the same kind, nothing happens; elsewhere, the battle is resolved using the "Rock-Papers-Scissors" rules: the Elite beats the Rookie, the Rookie beats the Waste, the Waste beats the Elite.
The winner takes the losing card as a point; the winning card cannot be attacked during the next round (current player passes clockwise).

Kagemucca was introduced in Mucca Games in 2006 by the author, Valerio Cassiano, who managed the First World Kagemucca (Preview) Tournament.

Valerio Cassiano passed away a few months later.

Kagemucca was produced by Mucca Games and daVinci Games in 2008, with the help of the Cassiano family, and of many Mucca Games friends.

The cows on the cards are illustrated by:

Simone Pacioni (the Original Ones!), Gianpaolo Derossi, Emanuela Matricardi, DRMA (Domenico, Roberta, Matteo, Andrea ) Di Giorgio, Daniele Barletta, Alberto Di Giorgio, Luigi Ferrini, Alberto Bontempi, Martina Mealli, Paolo Vallerga, Marco Giammetti, Giordano "Giò" Segatta, Martino Palladini.

Name: DECiMiX
Description:
DECiMiX is a game where the aim is to be the player scoring the most points at the end when all tiles have been placed.
There is a pool of tiles in the centre of the table, and each player has a hand of 5 tiles.  Each time a tile is placed, the player draws back up from the pool.
On each turn a player can play as many of their 5 tiles as they feel is advantageous - each tile played must adjoin a piece already on the board, and the numbers in each triangle of the tiles must add up to a total of 10.
Scores are made for completing squares of 4 pieces, and should be added to the players score tally as soon as the square is completed.

Name: Tenaha
Description:
Tenaha is a somewhat unique pattern matching and hand management domino game that requires 5 sets of Double Six dominoes, a draw bag and a set of poker chips (you need around 20 of the same color/pattern per player) to play.

The poker chips are used to mark completed sets (i.e. squares) and keep score.

Name: Election of the King
Description:
In Königswahl, each player takes the role of a medieval dynasty in the Holy Roman Empire between 1000 and 1600. Players start as bondsman and attempt to ascent ranks, with the goal to obtain ministry positions at the court of the kaiser. Each ministry equals one vote. The objective of the game is to gain enough votes to assign the new emperor after the old kaiser died.

By managing workers, building new buildings, trading with cities, raising taxes, diplomacy and using political influence, cultural development, population growth, and military actions, each player tries to reach specific conditions which qualify him/her for either secular or religious ascension. Moreover, each player has to guarantee the continuous existence of her/his dynasty by getting offspring and marrying offspring with the offspring of other players.

In each round, every player plans ahead 5 actions which, in most of the cases, can be played simultaneously. Seven different kinds of actions are possible (diplomacy/intrigue; get influence cards; income/trading; build; development; expansion; action upgrade), each of which can be improved up to five levels (except for "action upgrade"). 
The population size determines the number of workers a player commands. Workers are necessary for military expansion, operating buildings, trading with cities etc.

Name: America's History: Multicultural Contributions to America – Modern Age to Contemporary Period
Description: This is primarily a trivia game.  Players move around the board answering questions.  The player with the most correctly answered questions wins.  A set time period is used to determine when a particular game is completed.

Name: Code-Cracker
Description:
Each player has a rack with a row of six disks on top and a row of six disks on the bottom.  Each disk has numbers from 0 to 6.  The top row is adjusted by the players to form their 'secret codes' while the bottom is used to deduce the code of the opponent.

The codes are cracked by drawing question cards, which must be truthfully answered by the opponent.  The questions are in the form of simple mathematics involving the dials on the secret code, such as "what is the sum of the third and sixth figures" or "multiple the second figure by the fourth".

By collecting the information in this manner, the players try to deduce the secret code of their opponent, and the first to do so wins!

Name: The Pickle Game
Description: Ever wonder just how many kinds of pickles there are? Of course you haven't! But we did… Here players strategically change the ingredients in jars of pickle brine, each trying to achieve the correct ratio of ingredients to complete different pickle recipes.

Name: Mad Scientist: Frankenbuilder
Description: Play a Mad Scientist student, racing to animate your first monster! Send your unreliable assistants (Agor, Egor, Igor, Ogor, Ugor, or Ygor) to collect diverse body-parts from different graveyards, with the hope that you can cobble something together from the mis-matched parts.

Name: Mad Scientist: Lab Rats
Description: Players are Mad Scientist students chasing escaped, mutated lab rats throughout the Mad Scientist university. Each rat has developed different powers while being a lab rat (psychic rats, genius rats, giant rats, mutant rats, etc.), and they can put up one heck of a fight!

Name: Mad Scientist: Final Exam
Description: As Mad Scientist students, players collect, trade, and assemble hands of cards as they go through their crazy final exams. Hand ranks change during the round, causing players to bet on the winning hand and change strategies mid-game at the whim of capricious teachers.

Name: The Ten Commandments
Description:
Recreate the Ten Commandments with your friends! Each player has a set of goals for the final version of the Ten Commandments, and they debate and vote among themselves to get the Commandments that they want in the final ten.

Part of the Top Ten series. See also Top Ten: The Bill of Rights.

Name: Operation Phantom Fury
Description:
“Lead US Marines in the assault on Fallujah.”

This solo card game uses two decks of card, the American deck and the Insurgency deck. The American card types include Tactics, Infantry, Armor, Support, Recon, and Disarm. The Insurgency card types include Tactics, Insurgents, Positions, Explosives, and Objectives.

As the game is played, seven piles of cards are formed. Three piles represent the "Front Line", Insurgent positions 1, 2 and 3. There is also one pile for captured insurgents and objectives, one pile for American casualties, and two discard piles (one for each side.)

The game Ends when there are no cards left in the Insurgent Deck and the Front Line piles.

The player’s score is based on the total value of the cards in the captured pile less the total value of the cards in the casualty pile.

Name: America's History: Multicultural Contributions to America – Colonial Times to Reconstruction
Description: This is primarily a trivia game.  Players move around the board answering questions.  The player with the most correctly answered questions wins.  A set time period is used to determine when a particular game is completed.

Name: Kilts & Claymores
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Skirmish between two feuding Scottish Highland Clans. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill 6 or more opposing units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. Each side starts with sixteen units: a Chieftain, five Champions, and ten Clansmen. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Newsreel Trivia
Description: Newsreel Trivia is a board game which also comes with a VHS tape with original News footage from British Movietone from the 20th century.  The game contains a board, video, over 2000 questions, pawns and dice.

Name: Virginia Techopoly
Description:
A HOKIE GAME!
Have you ever fantasized about being the Hokie Bird? Or dreamed of owning Lane Stadium? If so, here’s your chance to do it all! VA TECHOPOLY is designed for alumni, students and fans of Virginia Tech. Choose your token and advance to Register and Proceed. You may soon be marching in the Corps of Cadets…or hanging out at Cook’s Laundromat!

Name: Sgt Bilko
Description:
Spin and move to operate "Bilko Promotions", acquire the most money and avoid the perils of army life. This game is based on the '50s TV show Sgt Bilko starring Phil Silvers. The game lasts until twelve 'promotions' are played, and players can bankrupt out of the game.

Contents:

circular board
blue cards 
yellow cards representing 'Bilko Productions'
play money 
spinner 
4 x playing counters

Name: Ox in die Box
Description: This isn't a game for lallygags, only speedy recognition and use of the space between the oxen legs will get you through.  Or perhaps the dogs, who can get through the legs of the oxen and out the gap.  Perhaps you will be the best farmer.

Name: Eye-Witness
Description:
Eye-Witness is a memory and bluffing game where a scene is presented on the board, modified by overlaying game cards, and then players vote and bluff on which and how many details they can remember.

The theme revolves around a bank-robbery in a downtown setting.

Pieces:

1 x board
72 x red picture cards
72 x green picture cards
24 x witness statement cards
1 x checking key card
1 x checking ruler
1 x scoring pad
1 x rules book
6 x counters (red on one side, green on the other)

Name: First Axis: Slovakia at War 1939-1945 – A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book
Description:
From the publisher:

In March 1939, the small nation of Slovakia declared its independence from Czechoslovakia and immediately became a satellite of Nazi Germany. Slovak troops became the first Axis forces to fight alongside the Germans, joining in the invasion of Poland in September 1939. They also marched into the Soviet Union in 1941. After five years as the most minor of allies, the Slovaks turned against the fascists and fought with the victorious Allies in the last year of the war.

First Axis is a 64-page book supplement to the Panzer Grenadier series, focused on the battles of the Slovak Army against the Hungarians, Poles, Soviets and Germans. There are 30 new scenarios plus background articles on the armies and weapons involved and unit organization diagrams. This module is not playable by itself, but requires ownership of Eastern Front: A Panzer Grenadier Game, Road to Berlin: Platoon Level Combat in World War II â€“ A Panzer Grenadier Game and White Eagles: A Panzer Grenadier Supplement Book to enjoy all of the scenarios.

First Axis includes 88 die-cut and mounted playing pieces. Almost all of them represent Slovak forces, including the small country's surprisingly large array of tanks. There are also a few new Hungarian tank pieces included. The book's format is the same as our very popular White Eagles: A Panzer Grenadier Supplement Book and Fronte Russo: A Panzer Grenadier Expansion Book books.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

Expands:

    Eastern Front: A Panzer Grenadier Game
    Road to Berlin: Platoon Level Combat in World War II â€“ A Panzer Grenadier Game
    White Eagles: A Panzer Grenadier Supplement Book

Name: Don't Tip the Waiter
Description:
Players start the game with three one-dollar bills. They then take turns selecting any size plate of food and placing it on the waiter’s tray. If the added plate makes the waiter tip and drop any of his plates, the player has to “tip” the waiter one dollar. A player is out of the game when he or she runs out of money. The last player with money remaining wins the game.

Very similar in theme and name to Don't Tip the Waiter and Don't Tip The Waiter.

Name: Courtroom Clash
Description:
Devil’s Playground‘s first board game release, Courtroom Clash; which is based off of the Open Gaming License; is a game of attorneys and trials for two players: the prosecution and the defense (solitaire is also possible). It covers both criminal and civil trials; for simplicity, the terms “prosecution” and “defense” are used here for both, though “plaintiff” and “defendant” are the correct civil case terms.  Courtroom Clash comes with all the materials needed to play the game in this single PDF which can be used for hours and hours of fun.

One six-sided die is required for play.

Name: Wing Commander Fighters
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Takes place in the Wing Commander Universe. Abstract skirmish level Fighter combat. Each figure represents a single Fighter. Victory: You win if you destroy the opposing Wing Commander."

The game provides statistics for seven Terran Confederation Fighters and seven Kilrathi Fighters. Each player starts with two Heavy, three Medium, and three Light Fighters of their selection. One Fighter must be designated the Wing Commander. The players assign a Pilot to each one of their Fighters. There are eight named pilots for each side and each pilot has a special advantage.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Phasers
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Star Trek Fleets. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Dreadnaught."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. The players choose to play as the Federation, Klingons, or Romulans. Each side has eight ships: three Destroyers, two Scouts, two Cruiers, and one Dreadnaught. The only distinction between the types of ships is the number of hits they can take.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Robotech Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Zentradi and the Robotech Defense Force. Takes place in the Robotech Universe. Each figure represents a single Battle Pod, Armor Suit, Veritech Fighter or Destroid. Victory: Destroy 10+ of the Hits of the opposing side or the opposing Commander."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units.

The game presents statistics for seven Robotech units and five Zentradi units. Each is rated for movement, hits, and up to ten special abilities (related to weaponry, defenses, or movement.) Each player purchases sixteen hits worth of units to start the game. One unit is designated the Commander.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Star Command
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between  Buzz Lightyear and Evil Emperor Zurg. Takes place in the Buzz Lightyear Universe. Each figure represents a main character or group of lesser characters. Victory: Capture the opposing Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the forces. Each side has sixteen units. The units are rated for hit points, movement, attack range, and special ability.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Martian Cloudships
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between a Band of Martian Cloudships and a British (Victorian) Expeditionary Force."

"Alternate Fantasy Universe circa late 1800’s. Abstract skirmish level aerial combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Note: Vessels achieve weightlessness by carrying quantities of distilled Essence of Ether. Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each player has eight ships and a unique deck of cards. The cards are central to the play of the game as card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: He-Man Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Choose your side: He-Man or Skeletor. Takes place in the Masters of the Universe setting. Each figure represents one Fighter. Victory: Destroy your opponents Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Action figures, miniatures or counters are used to represent fighters and vehicles. Each side has sixteen units plus vehicles.

Each player has a custom deck of cards. Card play is central to the game as it is used to determine when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: X-Men Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between  Mutants & Sentinel Robots. Takes place in the X-Men Universe. Each figure (unit) represents a Mutant or Robot. Victory: Destroy all opposing Units."

The X-Men get eight Mutants with a maximum Hit point total of 16. The Sentinel Robots and eighteen named Mutants are described by hit points, abilities, and three special powers.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Spelljammer Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Takes place in the Spell Jammer Universe. Pick your Fleet: Humans, Neogi, Elves, Beholders... Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship."

There are seventeen different fleets that the players may choose from. The fleets have between three and eight ships, each of which is rated for hits, class, and special abilities.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
Families: Versions & Editions: Board Game Versions of Role-Playing Games

Name: Moria Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between the Fellowship of the Ring and the Orcs of Moria. Abstract Skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill all the opposing figures."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the fighters. The Fellowship player has nine units and the Orc player has sixteen. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Wizard Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two rival Wizards. Each figure represents a Wizard or a Summoned Creature. Victory: Reduce the opposing Wizard to zero Hit Points."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units.

Each player starts with just their Wizard on the board. Summon Cards are played to summon monsters which are then controlled by that Wizard. The Wizards battle by using Spell Cards to attack their opponent as well as by making attacks with the summoned monsters. Card play determines how units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Narnia Skirmish
Description:
"Board and Card Game. Battle between Aslan and the Kingdom of Narnia against the White Witch and her minions. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents 1 creature (1:1 scale). Victory: The Narnian forces win if they either defeat the White Witch or her entire army. The White Witch wins if she defeats Aslan or the Army of Narnia."

The Forces of the Kingdom of Narnia include Aslan, the King of Narnia, a Duke, an Earl, four Archers, and eight Infantry. The Forces of the White Witch include fifteen assorted monsters in addition to the Witch herself.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Musketeer Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Melee between the 3 musketeers and a handful of the Cardinal's bodyguards. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure (unit) represents a single man. Victory: Eliminate your opponents completely."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Athos, Porthos and Aramis face off against a Captaion of the Cardinal's Guard and seven Guards. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

An optional scenario provides for adding D'Artagnan as a fourth musketeer and three additional Cardinal's Guards.

Name: Tanker Skirmish
Description:
A game of conflict between two armored forces. The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. A standard deck of cards is used. Red cards allow units to attack and black cards allow units to move.

Each side receives identical units: six Tanks, six Artillery, one Helicopter, and three Bases (a Command Post, Fuel Depot, and Ammo Dump.) The destruction of a Base has a negative effect on the player's other units.

The object of the game is to destroy all of the enemy Bases.

Name: Rockets & Rayguns Skirmish
Description:
"Will Flash rescue Dale or will they go down in flames aboard the Imperial Flagship. Find out in next weeks cliff hanger. Strap on your jetpack and get ready for some high flying adventure."

The Rebels are attacking the Imperial War Rocket Ajax where Heroine Dale is held prisoner. Aided by Chieftan Voltan of the Hawkmen and Forest Chieftan Baron, Human Hero Flash leads the Rebel force in its assault to board the Rocket and get to the brig to free Dale.

Victory is determined by which player scores the most Victory Points. The Rebels gain points for rescuing Dale and destroying the Rocket, and lose points for each Hero killed. The Imperials gain Victory Points for each Rebel Hero killed and for keeping Dale prisoner. The Imperials lose points if the Rocket is destroyed.

Name: Playground Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Fight between two groups of kids on the playground. Victory: Drive the opposing gang off the playground."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Eight to ten spaces are marked with obstacles such as Jungle Gyms, Monkey Bars, Teeter Tooters, Swings, Slides, etc.

Miniatures or counters are used to represent the kids. Each side has eight kids - two are on skateboards, two are on bikes, and 2 have skates.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Lightning Reaction Revenge
Description:
The game consists of four handles, each equipped with a button. Each player grabs a handle and the game is started. A red light starts to blink and a nasty wailing sound is played. Then, suddenly, the light will turn green and sound goes silent. At that point, players must push the button in their handle. The LAST player to do that gets an electrical shock. Players will also be shocked, if they push the button while the light is red.

"Extreme" mode : in this mode ONLY the fastest button pusher is safe, while the rest are shocked. Obviously this only makes a difference with 3 or 4 players. With 2, it plays identical to the original.

"Revenge" mode : in this mode each player chooses who they would like to shock if they were to win. Press the button on the handle until the red light on your base control is targeting your chosen victim. The 3 lights correspond as follows : centre is the player opposite, left is the player to your left and right is the player to your right. Start the game and the fastest finger gets to shock their chosen victim.

The game uses three AAA batteries, so the shock is not dangerous, but it certainly adds an element of tension to the otherwise rather simple test of reacting speed.

Re-implements:

    Lightning Reaction
    Lightning Reaction Extreme

Name: Star Trek Ship Engagements
Description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Star Trek Space Combat Theme. Each player controls 1 Ship. Victory: Destroy your opponent’s Ships."

The players share a custom card deck which contains cards representing Sensors, Weapons, Evasion, Surprise, Detection, Sabotage, Security, Shields, Critical Hits, and (of course) Engineering.

Each player picks an Empire and a Ship Class at the start of the game. There are three Empires in the game: Federation, Klingon, and Romulan. Each Empire uses different values for the Weapon, Defense, and Special cards.

The four ship classes are: Gun Ship, Frigate, Cruiser, and Capitol Ship. Each class is rated for structure points (the number of hits the ship can take) and hand size for the class.

When there are more than two players, teams can be formed.

Name: Marvel Ultimate Battles
Description: Aimed at a younger audience Marvel Ultimate Battles is a new easy-to-learn TCG featuring characters from the Marvel line of comics. Play as Captain America, Spider-Man, Wolverine and more in a fast-paced battle to to see who will be the last one left standing!

Name: Starship Troopers
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Human Troopers and the Arachnoid Threat. Each figure represents a Trooper or Insect(s). Victory: Kill the opposing Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. The Arachnoid player has sixteen units: eight Worker Swarms, seven Warrior Bugs, and a Queen. The Trooper player has seven Troopers and a Commander. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Name: Age of Enlightenment
Description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme: Age of Reason 18th Century. Players try to claim the most/best people and ideas from The Age of Enlightenment."

The game is played with two custom decks, the Personage Deck and the Discovery Deck. Only Personage Cards are held in a player's hand. The Discovery Cards are drawn and distributed for scoring purposes.

"The game ends when both decks have been used up.
The player with the most Enlightenment points wins." Each Discovery Card has a specified point value. Points are also awarded for having the most cards in a category (such as scientists, philosophers, and musicians.)

Name: Star Wars Fleets
Description:
"Card game for 2 players. Star Wars Universe Fleet Actions. Rebel Fleet vs Imperial Fleet."

"The Decks: Each player has their own unique deck. Cards: There are 4 types of cards - Capitol Ships, Fighter Squads, Personalities (captains or pilots), Action Cards."

"Objective: Reduce your opponent to zero Fleet Points."

Name: Stickin it to the Man
Description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Based on the Blacksploitation films of the early 70’s. Winning: The player accumulates the most Cool Points (CP) at the end of 5 hands wins."

The game is played with a custom deck containing seven suits of cards: Character, Cool, Fighting, Accessories, Bad Guys, Musician, and Actor. Each card is valued at 1 to 10 Cool Points.

Each turn the players play melds containing up to one card from each suit. The meld with the highest total Cool Point value wins the hand and the value of the hand is added to the player's Cool Point score.

Name: The Guardian
Description:
A U.S. Coat Guard themed game inspired by the movie of the same name.

"Mayday!!! Mayday!!! Two teams of U.S. Coastguard helicopter pilots, spotters, and rescue swimmers are racing against time as a large storm wreaks havoc across the high seas. Each team is attempting to rescue as many victims as possible. Victory: The team with the most rescues after 52 turns wins."

The components include an 8×8 board (the sea), one 8-sided die, one 6-sided die, two standard decks of cards (representing the ”search & rescue” and “operations” decks), twenty-five Coast Guard event cards, two Coast Guard team tokens, and six Disaster tokens (numbered 1-6.)

Name: Huscarl
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Norse Tribes. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Chieftain."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player has sixteen units: a Chieftain, three Huscarls, two Berserkers, eight Warriorss, and two Pathfinders.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Name: Legend of the Five Rings Skirmish
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Based on the Legend of the Five Rings Games. Each figure represents a Hero or a company or unit of men. Victory: You win if you kill your opponents Warlord."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. Each player has sixteen units: four Infantry, four Cavalry, four Archers, one Champion, one Shugenja, one Clan specific unit, and a Warlord.

The game describes eight Clans the players can choose from. Each Clan has a unique special unit and rules for how the clan can use Power Cards.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.
Families: Setting: Legend of the Five Rings

Name: Methuselah
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. One side is Dracula and his minions. The other side is the Vampire Hunter and his assistants. Action takes place inside Castle Dracula. Victory: You win if you kill your opponent’s Leader."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Vampire player has five Lesser Vampires, two Elder Vampires, and Methuselah. The Hunter player has a Lead Hunter, two Companions, and five Assistants.

Each player has a custom deck of cards. Card play is central to the game, as it determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Name: Russo-Turkish War
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Abstract simulation of the Russo-Turkish War of 1877. (Russia’s fifth war against Turkey (The Ottoman Empire) in the 19th Century.) One player is the Turks, the other is the Russians. Victory: Destroy all opposing units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. Each player starts with twelve units (representing 20,000 men each). Each unit can sustain three hits.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play controls how units move, attack, and defend. In addition, Recruit Cards may be played to bring back lost units.

Name: Operation Blitzkrieg
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. World War II theme. Abstract platoon level combat. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player starts with eight Infantry, four Tanks, and four Artillery.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

An Air War rules variant replaces two to four Infantry units with Air units. Additional attack, move, and defense cards are added to the deck for the Air units.

Name: Panzer
Description:
Panzer is a free print & play, card driven, armor combat game on a tactical level set in World War II for 2 players.

The game is played on hex maps with a scale of 500 meters per hex. Statistics are given for German, British, French, American and Russian tanks, and two German anti-tank guns. Each unit is rated for speed, armor, and penetration. Counters are used to represent the tanks, guns and various combat and terrain effects.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from a common deck affecting the way units move and attack. Intelligent and timely card play are paramount to achieving victory.

Panzer's design is clean and elegant with smooth mechanics and easy to learn, intuitive rules yet engrossing gameplay, perfectly suited for those new to board wargaming. Easy to set up, with sessions lasting about 45 minutes, Panzer has nearly unlimited replayability.

Name: Orbital Escalation
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Satellites in Earth Orbit. Each figure represents a satellite, shuttle, space station or space marine squad. Victory: Destroy or capture the opposing Battle Station."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the satellites. Each player has sixteen units, composed of one Battle Station, two Attack Shuttles, three Hunter Killer Satellites, three Orbital Weapons Platforms, three Zero-G Space Marines, and four Orbital Mines.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Monster Brawl
Description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Two Rival Gangs of Giant Japanese Monsters Face-off. Each figure represents a single Monster. Victory: Kill all opposing Monsters."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Action figures, toys, miniatures, or counters are used to represent the monsters.

The players each have forty points to spend on monsters. The game describes thirty giant monsters who are rated for cost, hit points, flight capability, and special abilities.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Name: Know Me Fast!
Description: Players write down what they believe will be the other players' answers to four questions on a card (such as favorite horror movie, number of piercings, "first or last"), with cards for everyone rotating such that one card will be associated with a particular player. All other players having guessed, the particular player will give their own answers, and matches are scored.

Name: Alam Halfa
Description:
Alam Halfa is an operational level simulation of the World War 2 battle between Axis and Allied forces around El Alamein in Egypt, conducted during the period of the 31st August to the 5th September 1942. Axis Field Marshall Erwin Rommel launched his attack against the Allied forces comprising the British 8th Army, in what was to become the last major offensive conducted by Axis forces in Egypt.

Alam Halfa comprises:

-One Rule book
-One Mapsheet (two halfs that overlap)
-One and a half counter sheets in full color (312 counters)
-Two cardstock support point charts
-Four unit strength roster sheets
-Two play aid cards in color
-Three Zip lock counter bags.

Name: España 1936: La Armada
Description:
España 1936 – La Armada is an expansion module for the original game EspaÃ±a 1936. This supplement includes game naval units of both sides, a strategic board for naval operations, 24 cards and a new set of rules to expand the game in its original edition in spanish.

The English edition of ESPAÑA 1936 already includes this set of counters, cards as well as the set of advanced naval rules for the game.

Produced in Christmas 2008.
Currently available for free at your shop or on demand to Devir Iberia


España 1936 – La armada es un modulo de expansión para el juego original EspaÃ±a 1936. Este suplemento de juego incluye las unidades navales de los dos bandos, un tablero estratégico para las operaciones navales, 24 nuevas cartas y un conjunto de reglas para ampliar el juego original en su edición en castellano.

La edición en ingles de ESPAÑA 1936 ya incluye este set de fichas, las cartas y las reglas navales así como como reglas avanzadas para el juego.

Producida en Navidades de 2008.
Actualmente disponible gratuitamente en tu tienda habitual o a la editorial Devir Iberia,

Name: Macskafogó
Description:
The game is based on a (Hungarian) animated movie from the 80s. The english title for the movie was Cat City. 
Grabowski the mouse plays against the rats Pissy, Buddy, Cookie and Billy and the cat Teufel. The aim of the game is to be the first to complete a puzzle. Grabowski gets a piece of his puzzle for arriving at the lab, the rats/cat get a piece of theirs if they manage to trap Grabowski.

Name: Colonization in Sicily
Description:
A player becomes a member and reclaims uncivilized ground Sicily.
All the actions, such as arranging an exploitation hut to a wilderness, expanding a city, or building, are decided by "Election". When you become a "Candidate", introduce a bill supported by the "Eligible voter". And when you become an "Eligible voter", vote for the most convenient bill for yourself. 
The player which contributed to exploitation and obtained most many scores is a winner.

Name: Quinio
Description:
This is an old 5 in a row game. In the box there is a playing field made of cardboard that fits nicely in the middle of the box. There are little plastic markers (like pins or nails) in 4 colours, that fit into holes in the playing board. A turn consists of putting one of your markers on a free spot on the board. You win if you are the first to get 5 in a row.

See also Go-Moku, 5 in a Row, Pegity.

Name: Immortal Fire: Greek, Persian and Macedonian Wars – Field of Glory Gaming Companion
Description:
The third army list supplement for the Field of Glory miniatures wargame. This supplement covers the armies of ancient Greece and the Hellenistic world, along with their allies and enemies. There are eighteen separate lists, each with a sample starter army and point cost chart for making your own force.

The book itself is 80 pages printed in full color with photos of miniatures and paintings from various other Osprey books used throughout.

Armies included:
- Classical Greek
- Early Achaemenid Persian
- Thracian
- Lydian
- Late Dynastic Egyptian
- Kyrenean Greek
- Early Carthaginian
- Skythian or Saka
- Classical Indian
- Late Achaemenid Persian
- Syracusan
- Alexandrian Macedonian
- Early Successor
- Early Sarmatian
- Galatian
- Hellenistic Greek
- Graeco-Bactrian
- Indo-Greek

Name: Old Course Golf & Country Club St. Andrews Golf Game
Description:
From the Box:The Old Course, St. Andrews

No one knows who the first golfer was but everyone knows where he played: The Old Course, St. Andrews, Scotland.

The first mention of the game was in 1457 and ever since then a succession of great champions have wrestled to master The Old Course. Now, the latest in a long line of champions, Seve Ballesteros, winner of the 1984 Open, here at St. Andrews, plays The Old Course as Touring Professional of The Old course Golf and Country Club.

The Old course Hotel, as it then was, was acquired by a major British public company in 1982 and a multi-million pound refurbishment programme was completed in April 1983 creating 150 luxury five star rooms, a health spa, restaurants and many other luxury amenities for the exclusive use of members of The Old Course Golf and Country Club.

The club offers a unique membership which gives members a passport to unparalleled golf facilities the world over and which includes many of the finest resorts both in europe and in the U.S.A., with luxurious, complimentary accomodation.

Jack Nicklaus, Bernhard Langer and Sean Connery are but a few of the well known members of this, the most prestigious club in the world-

The Old Course Golf and Country Club, St. Andrews.

Game: Played on full colour scale drawings of The Old Course.

Name: USAAF: US Strategic Bombing Operations Over the Third Reich, 1944
Description:
Best estimates today have it that the war in Europe most likely would have continued for about 24 months after February 1944 had it not been for the cumulative effects of the Allied strategic aerial offensive against the Germans. That means the war was most likely shortened somewhere between 13 and 15 months by the effects of that campaign. We say "most likely" and "somewhere between" because we can't be more certain. That is, starting at the end of 1944, the Western Allied and Soviet ground advances began to add their resource-denying effects to the successes being scored by the bombers. Where precisely the effects of the one effort picked up and the other left off is, and will likely always remain, a matter of debate.

We can, however, use that December 1944 cut off date to our advantage in this game. We know for certain that prior to that time any collapse of the German war effort would mostly certainly have been due to the bombings' effects. If the "Bomber Barons" were to prove they could win a war with their planes alone, we can now see they had to do it by that date. Thus the would-be Bomber Barons in today's wargame hobby must also bring their efforts to fruition by that time in the game in order to win.

In general, each "game turn" represents the cumulative effects of one month of aerial operations. Note, though, Game Turn 3 represents two calendar months. That's because a large portion of US aircraft strength was drawn away from this campaign during that time in order to assist in the battlefield preparation for the D-Day landings. There are a maximum of 10 game turns to each campaign.

The large-size, fully iconic, counters included with the game (176 total), are by famed artist Nicolas Eskubi. They represent air groups and wings, along with German FLAK brigades and divisions. Aside from all the formations historically involved in the campaign, an extended German Me-262 order of battle is included. That will allows players to determine, once and for all, exactly how many of those remarkable planes it would've taken to have finally and fully stopped the American onslaught.

Each large hex on the map represents 33.33 miles (54 Km) from side to opposite side. The game is of intermediate complexity, is intended for two players, and takes about six hours to complete.

Name: Les Belligérants
Description:
The Belligerents (A vivid game of Modern Combat) is one of the few pre-WWII wargames from France.  Featuring a board on heavy card stock with various terrain features and a superimposed grid for movement of units.  The game is driven by dice rolling and has units representing air, artillery, tank, ambulance, spy, guard, patrol and infantry.  Each unit has a value on the bottom to represent the impact of capture.

The rules have not been translated at this point but an update will follow.

Name: Le Grandi Manovre
Description:
Le Grandi Manovre - Nozioni di Arte Militare

The Great Maneuvers - Knowledge of the Military Art.   A full color 4 fold map representing a battlefield with elevations, tactical and operational targets as well as HQ and supply points.  Extremely advanced use of terrain and units.

There are multiple lead miniatures representing different artillery, tank, air units, cavalry, infantry and armored cars.  A chart of terrain and movement values is the center piece of the game (included on the inside of the box top) and this appears to be a true wargame created right before the advent of WWII.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Panzerschlacht
Description:
Panzerschlacht- Das Spannende Brettspiel:

Tank Battle - Exciting Board Game

The map consists of a rectangular board with three color squares (representing terrain and impassable areas) and starting lines.  The units consist of two sizes of tanks (small and large), both made of wood.

Each player has 10 small tanks and 8 big tanks. The tanks may move diagonaly in every direction. The small tanks have a moving range up to 6 spaces, while the big ones may move up to 4 spaces. Immediately after moving, the tanks may shot at an enemy tank. Shooting is only permitted straight ahead in the direction of the enemy encampment. The small tanks have a firing range of exactly 3 spaces, the big ones can shoot at tanks that are 3 or 4 spaces ahead. The dark green spaces can't be moved on, but can be shot over. When a tank is hit, it is removed from the game. If a tank neglects to shoot at an enemy, it may be removed by the enemy player. A tank, which has a friendly tank in the space in front of it, is protected from beeing shot at. If a tank reaches the enemy encampment, it reverses it's direction and attacks from the back. This makes a pincer tactic possible. The player who destroys the whole tank force of his opponent wins the game.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Klar Zum Gefecht
Description:
Klar zum Gefecht! Das packende Flottenspiel

Ready for the Fight! The Fleet Game

The map represents an ocean with 6 islands and contains a grid for movement, set up area for the red and blue fleet.  The fleets consist of battleships, cruisers, destroyers, u-boats, etc.  Each unit is a lead flat which is rare to find.

An update of the game flow and rules will follow but its primarily a die roll, move and attack game.

Name: TO-TO tärningsspel
Description: Horse racing game, where you roll 3 different dice, which indicates which horse you move and which way (forwards or backwards). Each player has a horse of a particular colour, and if yours finish first, you have won the game or that race, if you have decided to play several races.

Name: Scrabble Keychain
Description:
The classic crossword game, Scrabble, now on a key chain that features a magnetic game board surface, and 30 mini magnetic letter tiles! The mini magnetic Scrabble letters are stored in a secret drawer. Use your skills to cleverly connect letter tiles up, down and across the board.

This edition features a smaller board (11x11) and much fewer tiles (31) than standard Scrabble. Several letters are left out of the tile set completely including F, G, Q, Y, Z and more.

Name: Palaces of Minos
Description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Minoan Civilization Theme. Each player is a King on the island of Crete circa 2000 BC." Each player chooses to play one palace: Knossos, Phaistos, Malia, or Kato Zakros.

Two custom decks are shared by the players, a Trade Deck and a Build Deck. For each meld played with the Trade Cards, a player receives 1 to 16 Luxury Points (based on the type of meld played) and draws one card from the Build Deck. The Build Cards come in two types, Events (disasters) and Resources (bonuses).

The first player to accumulate 100 Luxury Points is the winner.

Name: POW
Description:
"Solitaire Card Game.You are a POW trying to survive and/or escape. Victory: You successfully escape if your total Escape level is ever +3. If you go through the whole deck and survive, you are sent back Home after the War ends. Death: If your Health level is ever –3 you die from physical ailments. If your Sanity level is ever –3 you lose the will to live and die."

The player has three characteristics that start at zero: Health, Sanity, and Escape. The cards lists events and activities that positively or negatively impact one of the three categories. Each turn, before drawing a card, a player may choose to adopt one of our attitudes: Early Escape, Good Behavior, Role Model, and Bad Behavior. Each attitude can modify a certain type of card.

Name: Prehistoric Warfare
Description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Each player controls a tribe (Band) of primitive human Foragers."

The game is played with a custom deck of cards. There are eleven types of cards in the deck: Hardship, Hunting/Gathering, Food, Strength, Persons, Hand-to-hand  Weapon, Ranged Missile Weapon, Defense, Tactics, Raiding, and Special Cards. Hunting Cards are played to gather food. Hardship Cards are played on other tribes. Raiding Cards are used to launch attacks on other tribes.

Additional sets of generic cards, or markers, are used to track the quantity of people, food, and prisoners in each tribe.

"The most primitive player goes first." There are two ways to win: if your tribe reaches a population of 30+ people cards, or if you eliminate all opposing tribes.

Name: Quest for the Princess Bride
Description:
"Card game for 2 players. Based on the Princess Bride Story. One player takes the role of Westly. The other player takes the role of Prince Humperdink."

The Humperdink player starts with control over Princess Buttercup. Both sides attempt to recruit allies as Character Cards are drawn. A fight may break out, randomly determined to be a battle of wits, strength, or sword. Card play determines the winning side. The winner of a fight gains or maintains control of the Princess.

"Victory: Any player able to control the Buttercup token for 4+ consecutive turns wins. Any player who loses his Main Character (Westly or Humperdink) in a fight automatically loses. If the deck runs out, the player in control of the Buttercup Token wins."

Name: Pluck-it
Description:
Carefully remove feathers without disturbing the eggs.
The player with the least number of eggs in their compartment is the winner!

Name: Somalia 93
Description:
"Card game for 2 players. Theme: The US Mogadishu Operation in Somalia on October 3, 1993. One player is the Americans. The other player is the Somalis."

Each side uses its own custom deck of cards. Each deck has three suits of cards. There are fifteen cards in each suit, each of which has a force value from 1 to 5.

The game consists of a series of card play battles where each side attempts to play cards having the highest Combat Force Total. The American force total is based on the play of Soldier, Weapon, and Tactics Cards. The Somali force total is based on the play of Combatant, Blunder, and Tactics Cards.

"If the Americans win 3 hands in a row, they are able to extract their comrades and escape. The game ends when this happens." The American player wins if the historical US casualty figure is not exceeded, otherwise the Somali player wins.

Name: Squad
Description:
"Card game. Simulates small unit tactics in World War II."

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. Tokens are used to represent soldiers. Two six-sided dice are also required.

"Each player starts with one squad of one of the five available nationalities. American squads start with 12 men. German, British, and Japanese squads start with 10 men. Russian platoons start with 36 men."

Differences between the nationalities are depicted in other ways, such as the number of cards drawn each turn and through National Trait Cards which have a different effect depending on which nationality plays the card. The rules also account for range, morale/rally, being pinned down, covering fire, opportunity fire, and terrain.

"Victory: There are two ways to win: Kill or rout all members of your opponents squad. Collect 3 Mission Objective Cards."
